answer_html: \(A=\begin{bmatrix} 1 1\\ 1 1 \end{bmatrix}.\) Notice that we can indeed confirm that this matrix has eigenvalues 2 and 0 and is not invertible.
answer_latex:
$A=\begin{bmatrix}
1    1\\
1    1
\end{bmatrix}.$ Notice that we can indeed confirm that this matrix has eigenvalues 2 and
0 and is not invertible.
hints_html: The matrix A has four unknowns. We are given 2 vector solutions of Ax=b. How can we turn this into 4 equations for our 4 unknowns?
hints_latex:
The matrix A has four unknowns. We are given 2 vector solutions of
A\textbf{x}=\textbf{b}. How can we turn this into 4 equations for our 4
unknowns?
hints_raw: The matrix A has four unknowns.  We are given 2 vector solutions of A'''x'''='''b'''.  How can we turn this into 4 equations for our 4 unknowns?
question: B 03 (c)
sols_html:
Let’s write our matrix A as

\[\begin{aligned} A= \begin{bmatrix} a & b\\ c & d \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

with yet to be determined entries. In the problem we know that

\[\begin{aligned} A \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} a & b\\ c & d \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

and we expand this out to get

\[\begin{aligned} a-b&=0,\\ c-d&=0.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore, a=b and c=d. We also have that

\[\begin{aligned} A \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} a & b\\ c & d \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 2 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

which we can expand out to get

\[\begin{aligned} a+b=2a&=2,\\ c+d=2c&=2.\end{aligned}\]

Therefore we conclude that a=b=c=d=1. Therefore our matrix A is

\[\begin{aligned} A= \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1\\ 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

Notice that we can indeed confirm that this matrix has eigenvalues 2 and 0 and is not invertible.
statement_html:
Let A be a \(2\times{2}\) matrix which transforms

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{to} \quad \begin{bmatrix} 2\\ 2 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

and transforms

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -1 \end{bmatrix} \quad \text{to} \quad \begin{bmatrix} 0\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

What is the matrix A?
statement_raw:
Let A be a <math>2\times{2}</math> matrix which transforms

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
1
\end{bmatrix} \quad \text{to} \quad \begin{bmatrix}
2\\
2
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

and transforms

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
-1
\end{bmatrix} \quad \text{to} \quad \begin{bmatrix}
0\\
0
\end{bmatrix}.
</math>

What is the matrix A?
